PGA.description: Peak Ground Acceleration (PGA), the maximum expected ground acceleration at the site due to earthquake shaking, reflecting short-period seismic demand that strongly affects stiff structures and foundations.

sentences: Very low PGA values from 0 to 0.2 indicate minimal seismic demand, typically requiring standard design considerations for stiff structures.
Low PGA values from 0.2 to 0.4 suggest mild seismic demand, necessitating basic seismic design measures to ensure structural integrity.
Moderate PGA values from 0.4 to 0.6 reflect significant seismic demand, requiring enhanced seismic design and detailing to prevent structural damage.
High PGA values from 0.6 to 0.8 indicate strong seismic demand, demanding rigorous seismic design and retrofitting to ensure safety and functionality.
Very high PGA values exceeding 0.8 represent extreme seismic demand, necessitating advanced engineering solutions and continuous monitoring to mitigate potential catastrophic failures.

SS.description: The mapped short-period spectral acceleration at the site before site soil effects are applied, representing seismic demand on short-period structural components.

sentences: Very low seismic demand (0 to 0.5) indicates minimal seismic forces on short-period structures, typically requiring standard design considerations.
Low seismic demand (0.5 to 0.8) suggests slightly increased seismic forces, necessitating enhanced design measures for short-period structures.
Moderate seismic demand (0.8 to 1.2) represents significant seismic forces, requiring robust design and detailing for short-period structures to ensure safety.
High seismic demand (1.2 to 1.6) indicates strong seismic forces, demanding advanced engineering solutions and rigorous compliance with seismic codes.
Very high seismic demand (1.6 to infinity) represents extreme seismic forces, necessitating specialized engineering strategies and continuous monitoring to maintain structural integrity.

S1.description: The mapped 1.0-second spectral acceleration at the site before site soil effects are applied, representing seismic demand on longer-period structural systems.

sentences: Very low seismic demand from 0 to 0.2 indicates minimal seismic forces on longer-period structures, suggesting low risk of seismic damage.
Low seismic demand from 0.2 to 0.4 suggests minor seismic forces, requiring basic seismic design considerations for structural safety.
Moderate seismic demand from 0.4 to 0.6 indicates significant seismic forces, necessitating robust seismic design and detailing to ensure structural resilience.
High seismic demand from 0.6 to 0.8 represents substantial seismic forces, requiring advanced seismic design strategies and potential retrofitting for existing structures.
Very high seismic demand exceeding 0.8 indicates extreme seismic forces, necessitating specialized engineering solutions and continuous monitoring to ensure structural integrity.

SMS.description: The site-adjusted short-period spectral acceleration that accounts for local soil amplification or attenuation of seismic ground motions.

sentences: Low amplification from 0 to 0.7 indicates minimal soil impact on seismic ground motions, suggesting a stable site with low seismic risk.
Moderate amplification from 0.7 to 1.0 reflects a noticeable increase in seismic ground motion due to soil conditions, requiring standard seismic design considerations.
High amplification from 1.0 to 1.3 indicates significant soil-induced amplification, necessitating enhanced seismic design measures to ensure structural safety.
Very high amplification from 1.3 to 1.6 suggests substantial soil effects on seismic ground motions, demanding rigorous engineering analysis and potentially advanced mitigation strategies.
Extreme amplification exceeding 1.6 represents severe soil amplification effects, posing high seismic risk and requiring comprehensive site-specific seismic assessments and interventions.

SDS.description: The design-level short-period spectral acceleration used directly in seismic design, reflecting reduced demand consistent with code-defined performance objectives.

sentences: Low seismic demand from 0 to 0.5 indicates minimal seismic forces, allowing for basic design considerations with standard safety margins.
Moderate seismic demand from 0.5 to 0.75 requires enhanced design measures to ensure structural resilience against moderate seismic events.
High seismic demand from 0.75 to 1.0 necessitates robust design strategies to withstand significant seismic forces, ensuring safety and functionality.
Very high seismic demand from 1.0 to 1.25 demands advanced engineering solutions and materials to maintain structural integrity during severe earthquakes.
Extreme seismic demand exceeding 1.25 represents outlier conditions requiring specialized design and construction techniques to prevent catastrophic failure.

SDCS.description: The seismic design category that classifies overall seismic risk at the site and governs required detailing, analysis rigor, and design provisions.

code_map.A: Very low seismic hazard conditions where seismic detailing and design requirements are minimal or not required.
code_map.B: Low seismic hazard conditions where limited seismic design and detailing provisions apply.
code_map.C: Moderate seismic hazard conditions where seismic forces and ductile detailing requirements begin to significantly influence design.
code_map.D: High seismic hazard conditions requiring substantial seismic design forces, ductile detailing, and explicit consideration of inelastic behavior.
code_map.E: Very high seismic hazard conditions where extreme ground motions are expected and the most stringent seismic design and detailing requirements apply.
code_map.F: Site-specific extreme seismic hazard conditions requiring specialized analysis, evaluation, and design beyond standard code procedures.

PGAM.description: The mapped peak ground acceleration associated with maximum considered earthquake conditions prior to any site-specific adjustments.

sentences: Very low seismic demand from 0 to 0.3 indicates minimal structural impact during seismic events, requiring standard design considerations.
Low seismic demand from 0.3 to 0.5 suggests minor structural impacts, necessitating basic seismic design enhancements.
Moderate seismic demand from 0.5 to 0.7 requires significant seismic design measures to ensure structural integrity during earthquakes.
High seismic demand from 0.7 to 1.0 indicates substantial structural impacts, demanding advanced seismic design and retrofitting strategies.
Very high seismic demand exceeding 1.0 represents extreme conditions, requiring specialized engineering solutions and continuous monitoring.

FPGA.description: The peak ground acceleration adjusted for local site conditions, representing the ground motion intensity expected to be experienced at the bridge location.

sentences: Low seismic demand from 0 to 0.8 indicates minimal ground motion impact, suggesting standard design measures are sufficient for bridge safety.
Moderate seismic demand from 0.8 to 1.2 suggests increased ground motion, requiring enhanced design considerations for seismic resilience.
High seismic demand from 1.2 to 1.5 indicates significant ground motion, necessitating advanced seismic design and retrofitting strategies to ensure bridge integrity.
Very high seismic demand from 1.5 to 2.0 represents severe ground motion, demanding comprehensive seismic engineering solutions and continuous monitoring.
Extreme seismic demand exceeding 2.0 represents outlier conditions with potential catastrophic ground motion, requiring specialized engineering interventions and emergency preparedness.
